title: Dino Meneghin
text:
Dino Meneghin (, ; born January 18, 1950) is an Italian former professional <a href="basketball">basketball</a> player. He is widely considered to be the best Italian player ever, as well as one of Europe's all-time greats. A 2.06 m (6 ft 9 in) tall <a href="center%20%28basketball%29">center</a>, Meneghin was born in <a href="Alano%20di%20Piave">Alano di Piave</a>, <a href="Veneto">Veneto</a> (northeast <a href="Italy">Italy</a>). On November 20, 1966, when he was 16 years old, he played in his first game in the <a href="Lega%20Basket%20Serie%20A">Italian League</a>, with <a href="Ignis%20Varese">Ignis Varese</a>. He played the last game of his career at the age of 45. In 2003, Meneghin became a <a href="List%20of%20players%20in%20the%20Naismith%20Memorial%20Basketball%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Basketball Hall of Fame player</a> and in 2010, he became a <a href="FIBA%20Hall%20of%20Famer">FIBA Hall of Fame player</a>.
Professional career.
In total, Meneghin played in 836 games and scored 8,560 points in the <a href="Lega%20Basket%20Serie%20A">Italian League</a> championship. Meneghin became the second player from a European league to be drafted by an <a href="National%20Basketball%20Association">NBA</a> team, when the <a href="Atlanta%20Hawks">Atlanta Hawks</a> manager <a href="Marty%20Blake">Marty Blake</a> selected him with a late-round pick in the <a href="1970%20NBA%20draft">1970 NBA draft</a>. He never played in the USA, however.
In 1980 and 1983, he was elected European Player of the Year: <a href="Mr.%20Europa">Mr. Europa</a>, and he also won the <a href="Euroscar">Euroscar</a> European Player of the Year award in 1983. In 1991, he was named the greatest FIBA European Champions' Cup (<a href="EuroLeague">EuroLeague</a>) basketball player of all time, by the Italian basketball magazine Giganti del Basket. 
One of the greatest records of his career is his number of <a href="EuroLeague%20Finals">Finals</a> appearances in the <a href="EuroLeague">FIBA European Champions Cup (EuroLeague)</a>. He played in 10 consecutive finals with <a href="Pallacanestro%20Varese">Pallacanestro Varese</a>, winning 5; and later in 2 more consecutive finals with <a href="Pallacanestro%20Olimpia%20Milano">Olimpia Milano</a>, winning both. Finally, before his playing career ended, Meneghin played in the Italian League against his son, <a href="Andrea%20Meneghin">Andrea</a>, who was also a great international player.
On 28th of October 2019, 25 years after he last played professionally, <a href="Olimpia%20Milano">Olimpia Milano</a> retired the number 11 in honor of Meneghin. The number 11 matched the number of seasons that he had played with the Italian club.
National team career.
With the senior <a href="Italy%20national%20basketball%20team">Italian national basketball team</a>, Meneghin played in 271 <a href="cap%20%28sports%29">games</a>, and totaled 2,847 points scored. With Italy, he won the bronze medal at both the <a href="1971%20EuroBasket">1971 EuroBasket</a> and the <a href="1975%20EuroBasket">1975 EuroBasket</a>. He also won the silver medal at the <a href="Basketball%20at%20the%201980%20Summer%20Olympics">1980 Summer Olympics</a>, and the gold medal at the <a href="1983%20EuroBasket">1983 EuroBasket</a>.
Post-playing career.
On September 5, 2003, Meneghin became the second Italian player to enter into the <a href="List%20of%20players%20in%20the%20Naismith%20Memorial%20Basketball%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Basketball Hall of Fame</a>, after <a href="Cesare%20Rubini">Cesare Rubini</a>, who served <a href="Pallacanestro%20Olimpia%20Milano">Olimpia Milano</a>, both as player and <a href="basketball%20coach">coach</a> between the 1940s and the 1970s. After his playing career ended, Meneghin has since worked for the <a href="Italian%20Basketball%20Federation">Italian Basketball Federation</a> and for <a href="Pallacanestro%20Olimpia%20Milano">Olimpia Milano</a>.
Personal life.
Dino Meneghin is the father of <a href="Andrea%20Meneghin">Andrea Meneghin</a>, who also played professional basketball. Andrea played against his father, during the latter's last season as a pro.
